title: Q&A: Colorado's Latina legislators giving voice to their communities
description: Betty Benavidez strove to improve access to better education in her west Denver neighborhood. She worked in her local schools and founded action centers, belonged to the Hispanic Education Leadership Program and the West High School PTA, and was district captain for the Democratic party to mobilize Mexican-American voters.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Exploring stellar hydrogen burning via muons and nuclei
description: The muon is a subatomic particle that resembles an electron but is 200 times heavier. It interacts with nuclei through the weak force, one of the four fundamental forces in the universe. When a muon binds with a deuteron (composed of one proton and one neutron), it forms a system with two neutrons. This process is analogous to proton-proton fusion, where two protons combine to form a deuteron.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Simultaneous large wildfires will increase in Western US, says study
description: Simultaneous outbreaks of large wildfires will become more frequent in the Western United States this century as the climate warms, putting major strains on efforts to fight fires, new research shows.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Recent research expedition reveals alarming extent of coral mortality in Florida
description: Scientists from Chicago's Shedd Aquarium, a leader in conservation research, returned from a multi-institutional research expedition to survey coral bleaching impacts from Miami and the Florida Keys to the Dry Tortugas, following an unprecedented rise in ocean temperatures.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Invertebrate biodiversity is improving in England's rivers, long-term trends show
description: Rivers across England have seen a significant improvement in river invertebrate biodiversity since 1989, shows a study led by UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology (UKCEH) researchers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 2023 GAP Report: Only by working together will agricultural productivity meet demand
description: Agricultural productivity growth is crucial for ensuring food security and for meeting the nutritional needs of a growing global population while simultaneously meeting environmental goals.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Extracellular vesicles study outlines new strategies to combat neurodegenerative diseases
description: A new study by the University of Barcelona could drive the design of future strategies to regenerate damaged brain areas in neurodegenerative diseases. The study emphasizes the role of neuron-derived extracellular vesicles in the processes that modulate synaptic plasticity and neuronal signaling pathways. In addition, the results outline a new scenario for using these extracellular vesicles derived from healthy neurons—capable of transporting molecules between cells—in treatments against neurodegenerative diseases.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research finds that ancient carbon in rocks releases as much carbon dioxide as the world's volcanoes
description: A new study led by the University of Oxford has overturned the view that natural rock weathering acts as a CO2 sink, indicating instead that this can also act as a large CO2 source, rivaling that of volcanoes. The results, published today in the journal Nature, have important implications for modeling climate change scenarios.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study identifies jet-stream pattern that locks in extreme winter cold, wet spells
description: Winter is coming—eventually. And while the Earth is warming, a new study suggests that the atmosphere is being pushed around in ways that cause long bouts of extreme winter cold or wet in some regions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Pandemic found to have boosted gardening, hunting in New York State
description: A survey of New York state residents found that nearly half of respondents increased the amount of time they spent on wild and backyard food in the early months of the COVID-19 pandemic—confirming anecdotes about increases in activities such as sourdough baking, fishing and gardening.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hot weather hits productivity—even in air-conditioned factories
description: Hot weather reduces workers' productivity—even if their workplace is air conditioned, new research shows.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: AI analyzes bird sightings to help conserve species
description: For the first time, big data and artificial intelligence are being used to model hidden patterns in nature—not just for one bird species, but for entire ecological communities across continents.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Professor helps accounting research catch up with a fast-changing economy
description: It's a time of transformation for capital markets. And Maria Nykyforovych, assistant professor of accounting at George Mason University School of Business, believes that accounting research can help resolve the confusions of economic change. But scholars must update their thinking first.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Underappreciation of LGBT executives creates investment opportunity, says study
description: Academics from Northumbria University have uncovered an "extreme underappreciation" of firms with CEOs who are openly gay, lesbian, trans or bisexual—and they say it's driven by discrimination.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Machine learning reveals how to dissolve polymeric materials in organic solvents
description: Dissolving polymers with organic solvents is the essential process in the research and development of polymeric materials, including polymer synthesis, refining, painting, and coating. Now more than ever recycling plastic waste is a particularly imperative part of reducing carbon produced by the materials development processes.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Pandemic posed vocabulary challenges for preschoolers, study reveals
description: When it came to learning language, money mattered for pandemic preschoolers, according to a new study out of U of T Mississauga's Child Language and Speech Studies (CLASS) Lab.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Seabird couples with similar personalities make better parents, finds study
description: Seabird couples with similar personalities are more likely to be successful parents, which in turn makes them less likely to seek another partner, according to a new study by the University of Liverpool.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How proteins roll the dice to determine bee sex
description: To date it has been unclear exactly how the sex of a bee is determined. A research team from Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf (HHU) including biologists and chemists has now identified a key gene and the molecular mechanism linked with it. In the current issue of the journal Science Advances, they describe how this process is similar to a game involving two dice.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study shows signs of early creation of modern human identities
description: Early ancestors collected eye-catching shells that radically changed the way we looked at ourselves and others. A new study confirms previous scant evidence and supports a multistep evolutionary scenario for the culturalization of the human body.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ruffed grouse population more resilient than expected, genetic study finds
description: Despite decades of decline, a genetic analysis of ruffed grouse reveals that Pennsylvania's state bird harbors more genetic diversity and connectivity than expected. The findings suggest that the iconic game bird could be maintained in persistent numbers if appropriate protections are implemented. The study, led by Penn State and Pennsylvania Game Commission researchers, is published in Molecular Ecology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Three giants of chemistry connected by the quantum realm
description: This year's Nobel Chemistry winners are pioneers in the nanoworld.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Brazil vows more aid as Amazon waters dry up
description: Brazil's Vice-President Geraldo Alckmin said Wednesday that more help would be sent to an Amazon state where rivers are drying up in a severe drought, causing mass die-offs of fish and dolphins.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Oops! Nobel chemistry winners are announced early in rare slip-up
description: The most prestigious and secretive prize in science ran headfirst into the digital era Wednesday when Swedish media got an emailed press release revealing the winners of the Nobel Prize in chemistry and the news prematurely went public.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Demystifying the role of plant x- and y-type thioredoxins
description: The potential for exposure to fluctuating light has necessitated that plants evolve protective mechanisms for when the light intensity exceeds photosynthetic capacity. Under these conditions, reactive oxygen species cause photoinhibition, which hinders photosynthetic efficiency. To counter this loss in photosynthetic efficiency, chloroplasts evolved thioredoxin (Trx) proteins that regulate redox balance within the photosynthetic apparatus and provide a photoprotective function.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Navigating moiré physics and photonics with band offset tuning
description: When two lattices with distinct angles or periodicities come together, they conjure a moiré superlattice—a realm where astonishing phenomena like superconductivity and optical solitons spring to life. At the heart of this realm lies the moiré flatband, a key player in shaping advanced light–matter interactions, such as laser emission and second harmonic generation. In moiré physics and its relevant applications, wielding control over flatbands is a pivotal superpower.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: US drinking water often contains toxic contaminants, scientist warns
description: Most Americans take it for granted that the water that comes out of their taps is clean and safe to drink.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Biodegradable bags not currently recommended for recycling organic waste
description: Bags made from biodegradable materials for collecting organic household waste have been available on the market for several years. Now researchers in a large-scale pilot study have conducted an extensive investigation into whether these bags fully decompose. In addition, a first-of-its-kind study also took a look into the consumers interest in using biodegradable bags.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ancient technology turns plant-based cheese into 'something we want to eat'
description: To produce plant-based cheeses that feel and taste like dairy cheese, scientists have their sights set on fermentation. In a new research result, University of Copenhagen scientists demonstrate the potential of fermentation for producing climate-friendly cheeses that people want to eat.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Prototype device to sniff out illegal wildlife trade
description: More than 90% of illegal wildlife products are transported around the world via shipping routes, but fewer than 2% of all shipping containers are physically inspected.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Team develops superhydrophobic surface that can stay dry for months underwater
description: A species of spider lives its entire life underwater, despite having lungs that can only breathe atmospheric oxygen. How does it do it? This spider, known as the Argyroneta aquatica, has millions of rough, water-repellent hairs that trap air around its body, creating an oxygen reservoir and acting as a barrier between the spider's lungs and the water.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Meadow spittlebug's record-breaking diet also makes it a top disease carrier for plants
description: New research fueled in part by citizen scientists reveals that the meadow spittlebug—known for the foamy, spit-like urine released by its nymphs—can feed on at least 1,300 species of host plants, more than twice the number of any other insect.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: MXene and MBene compounds can be engineered to selectively capture carbon dioxide, says study
description: Some of the thinnest materials known to mankind may provide solutions to scientists in their quest to curb the effects of global warming.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Space needs better 'parking spots' to stay usable, and an engineer is finding them
description: Any mission headed to space needs a "parking spot" at its destination. But these parking spots, regions located on orbits, are quickly becoming occupied or more vulnerable to collisions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Sycamore Gap: What the long life of a single tree can tell us about centuries of change
description: Only a few individual trees could be rightly labeled as world famous, but the tree at Sycamore Gap along Hadrian's Wall in northern England was one of them. No wonder its recent felling provoked public outcry and collective mourning.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Understanding greenhouse gases in oil palm plantations
description: The rapid spread of oil palm plantations and associated high use of fertilizer raises concerns about the emission of nitrous oxide (N2O), a powerful greenhouse gas. A new study by an international research team led by the University of Göttingen shows that oil palms' photosynthesis and their response to meteorological and soil conditions play an important but still widely unexplored role in the amount of N2O produced by oil palm plantations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Astronomers watched a massive star disappear. JWST might have some answers
description: In 2009 a giant star 25 times more massive than the sun simply vanished. OK, it wasn't quite that simple. It underwent a period of brightening, increasing in luminosity to a million suns, just as if it was ready to explode into a supernova. But then it faded rather than exploding. And when astronomers tried to see the star using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT), Hubble and the Spitzer space telescope, they couldn't see anything.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Adoption of vegan dog and cat diets could have environmental benefits
description: A new analysis estimates a variety of potential benefits for environmental sustainability—for instance, reduced freshwater consumption and greenhouse gas emissions—that could result from switching all pet dogs and cats in the US or around the world to nutritionally sound, vegan diets. Andrew Knight of Griffith University, Australia, presented these calculations in the open-access journal PLOS ONE.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Analysis of grinding tools reveals plant, pigment and bone processing in Neolithic northern Saudi Arabia
description: In recent years, studies have revealed that the now-arid region of northern Arabia was once much wetter and greener, providing Neolithic human populations with access to both water and game. The present aridity of the region, however, preserves little organic matter, making a reconstruction of the Neolithic lifestyle difficult.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hippos' prominent tusks and wide gaping mouths prevent efficient chewing, study shows
description: Hippos' huge tusks and wide gape restrict grinding jaw movements, making their chewing inefficient, according to a study by Annika Avedik and Marcus Clauss at the University of Zurich, Switzerland published in the open-access journal PLOS ONE.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers find that early human migrants followed lush corridor-route out of Africa
description: An international team of scientists has found early human migrants left Africa for Eurasia, across the Sinai peninsula and on through Jordan, over 80,000 years ago.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study of more than 330,000 genomes indicates 34 genes potentially involved in vegetarianism
description: Certain variations in genes involved in lipid metabolism and brain function may be associated with choosing a vegetarian diet, according to a new study led by Nabeel Yaseen of Northwestern University, published in the open-access journal PLOS ONE.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows prehistoric people occupied upland regions of inland Spain in even the coldest periods of the last Ice Age
description: Paleolithic human populations survived even in the coldest and driest upland parts of Spain, according to a study published October 4, 2023 in the open-access journal PLOS ONE by Manuel Alcaraz-Castaño of the University of Alcalá, Spain, Javier Aragoncillo-del Rió of the Molina-Alto Tajo UNESCO Global Geopark, Spain and colleagues.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NGOs accuse Bayer of hiding glyphosate risk data
description: An NGO grouping said Wednesday it had filed claims in an Austrian court alleging that chemicals firm Bayer withheld data showing health risks from exposure to its herbicide glyphosate, which the EU has proposed to keep using for 10 more years.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How secondary mathematics teachers' beliefs and knowledge influence their teaching in mainland China
description: Past research on Chinese mathematics teaching has focused mainly on the role of teacher's beliefs and professional knowledge separately in teaching approaches, or examined three variables—teacher's beliefs, professional knowledge and teaching approaches—in correlational studies. How teaching beliefs and professional knowledge specifically influence teaching approaches remained largely unclear. Also, most studies have focused on pre-service or elementary school teachers in the West. There is a need to know whether these conceptual frameworks can be applied and adapted to the Chinese teaching context at the secondary level.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study identifies trend toward larger and fewer eyespot patterns on butterflies
description: Eye spots, color patterns that resemble the eyes of vertebrates, on butterfly wings are common in nature. A research team involving the Leibniz Institute for the Analysis of Biodiversity Change (LIB) and researchers in Mexico, Brazil and the U.S., have now identified a trend towards fewer and bigger eyespots in a group of tropical butterflies in a DNA-based study.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: SpaceX aims for its 50th Space Coast launch this year
description: SpaceX is targeting its 50th Space Coast launch of the year with another Starlink mission from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Diagnosing anthropogenic carbon emissions: A 'carbon dioxide checkup' of Earth's health
description: Since 2020, many countries have pledged their plans for "carbon peak and carbon neutrality". Managing anthropogenic emissions, especially from major industries, is crucial for addressing global warming and promoting sustainable growth. However, existing emission records lack transparency and accuracy due to limited knowledge of CO2 emissions from cities and key sectors, leading to uncertainty in the global carbon budget and hindering carbon asset management across industries.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How llamas help mitigate effects of climate change
description: Introducing llamas (Llama glama) into land exposed by retreating glaciers can speed the establishment of stable soils and ecosystem formation, mitigating some of the harmful effects of climate change, according to experimental research conducted by scientists at The University of Texas at Austin and partner institutions in Peru.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change emerges as major driver of amphibian declines, new research finds
description: Amphibians are in trouble and in desperate need of conservation action, according to a new global assessment of the world's amphibian population.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate scientist 'could lose job' for refusing to fly
description: A climate scientist on Wednesday said he was being threatened with the sack for refusing to fly back to Germany from a research trip in Papua New Guinea.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change primary driver of amphibian decline: Study
description: Climate change has become the main factor driving amphibians towards extinction as they remained the most threatened vertebrates over the past two decades, according to research published on Wednesday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Advancing biodiversity research: New initiative bridges biodiversity and omics data standards
description: Biodiversity observation and research rely more and more on biomolecular data. The standardization of this data, encompassing both primary and contextual information (metadata), is crucial for enabling data (re-)use, integration, and knowledge generation. While both the biodiversity and the omics research communities have recognized the urgent need for (meta)data standards, they each have historically developed and adopted their own standards, making collaboration and data integration challenging.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Humans increasingly settling in high-risk flood zones, study warns
description: Humans are increasingly settling in areas highly exposed to dangerous flooding, a study warned Wednesday, with China helping drive the rise in risky urban expansion into exposed areas.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nobel chemistry winner flunked first college chemistry exam
description: Talk about bouncing back. MIT professor Moungi Bawendi is a co-winner of this year's Nobel chemistry prize for helping develop "quantum dots"—nanoparticles that are now found in next generation TV screens and help illuminate tumors within the body.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Microplastics in the mud: Finnish lake sediments help us get to the bottom of plastic pollution
description: The sun is shining, and air feels surprisingly warm when we walk on a 35cm ice that covers a frozen lake in central Finland. The heavy sledges move nicely, because there is not much snow on the ice today. The journey isn't far either, as we're by the city of Kuopio, which is surrounded by Finland's 10th largest lake. Despite the temperature of -10˚, I need to take off my hat—the sun in early March is already warm, or it could be the fact that the heavy sledge is following me obediently.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Quantum dots: the tiny 'rainbow' crystals behind chemistry Nobel
description: Quantum dots are tiny crystals that scientists can tune to different colors, giving an extra-vivid pop to next-generation TV screens or illuminating tumors inside bodies so surgeons can hunt them down.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: AI-generated misinformation: 3 teachable skills to help address it
description: In my digital studies class, I asked students to pose a query to ChatGPT and discuss the results. To my surprise, some asked ChatGPT about my biography.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researcher working to revitalize an Indigenous language and bring it into the future
description: Language is foundational to Indigenous communities, including my own, and a vital connection to our cultures.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists discover how the SARS-CoV-2 virus initiates replication program in infected cells
description: How SARS-CoV-2 initiates its replication process during infection is not yet fully understood. Researchers from the Helmholtz Institute Würzburg have now shown for the first time in the journal Cell that it is the human protein SND1 that works together with the viral protein NSP9 to stimulate the virus's genetic replication program in infected cells.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A precise test of quantum electrodynamics: Measuring the g factor of electrons in hydrogen-like tin
description: Quantum electrodynamics is the best-tested theory in physics. It describes all electrical and magnetic interactions of light and matter. Scientists at the Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik in Heidelberg (MPIK) have now used precision measurements on their Alphatrap experiment to investigate the magnetic properties of electrons bound to highly ionized tin atoms. Such tests provide insights into the behavior of particles under extreme field strengths. They also serve as a starting point for the search for new physics.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hubble records rare radio galaxy NGC 612
description: A striking orange and blue streak fills this new image from NASA's Hubble Space Telescope. Hubble's visible and infrared capabilities captured this edge-on view of lenticular galaxy NGC 612. Lenticular galaxies have a central bulge and disk much like spiral galaxies, but they lack the characteristic arms. They typically have older star populations and little ongoing star formation. In NGC 612, dust and cool hydrogen gas make up the majority of the galactic disk, the plane of matter we see in orange and dark red. This galaxy appears in the Sculptor constellation and is easily visible from Earth's southern hemisphere.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA's OSIRIS-REx spacecraft views sample return capsule's departure
description: After years of anticipation and hard work by NASA's OSIRIS-REx (Origins, Spectral Interpretation, Resource Identification and Security—Regolith Explorer) team, a capsule of rocks and dust collected from asteroid Bennu returned to Earth on Sept. 24 in a targeted area of the Department of Defense's Utah Test and Training Range near Salt Lake City.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Learning is easier with a positive attitude, finds meta-study
description: Students who think positively about their own abilities and their subject are more likely to achieve the goals they have set for themselves. Conversely, a lack of confidence in one's own abilities can lead to goals being missed. This is shown by a meta-study conducted by the DIPF | Leibniz Institute for Research and Information in Education and other institutions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The cat larynx can produce purring sounds without cyclical neural input
description: A recent investigation led by voice scientist Christian T. Herbst from the University of Vienna, published in Current Biology, delivers novel insights into how cats produce their purring sounds. A special "pad" embedded in the vocal folds might explain why the cats can produce these low-frequency sounds.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study: Climate, population structure impact oakleaf hydrangea genetic diversity
description: Oakleaf hydrangea (Hydrangea quercifolia) is an understory shrub native to the southeastern United States. The species occupies a small native range, and little is known about its demography, genetic diversity, or needs for conservation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study uses social media and machine learning to show environmental injustices in Philadelphia's urban parks
description: In urban areas throughout the United States, it is imperative for all communities to have equal access to high quality parks. These parks can have many benefits for the physical and mental well-being of the residents who live in close proximity to the urban green spaces. For instance, they are a place to socialize and exercise outdoors while also providing vegetation nearby, which can help reduce urban heat.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Life-size images of extinct camel species found carved into stones in Saudi Arabia
description: An international team of archaeologists has discovered life-size images of an extinct camel species carved into rock formations in Saudia Arabia. In their project, reported in the journal Archaeological Research in Asia, the group discovered the carvings on a rock outcropping in the Nefud desert.

title: Filling the data gap for volcanic ash effects on Earth systems

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Molecular knots, left and right: How molecules form knots
description: Helical molecules, similarly to a corkscrew, have a spiral shape that can be either left- or right-turning. Such "chiral molecules" can collectively organize (assemble) into large left- or right-handed twisted structures. These exhibit special optical properties and produce splendid colors, for example, in some insects.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nationwide test of Wireless Emergency Alert system could test people's patience—or rebuild trust in the system
description: The Wireless Emergency Alert system is scheduled to have its third nationwide test on Oct. 4, 2023. The Wireless Emergency Alert system is a public safety system that allows authorities to alert people via their mobile devices of dangerous weather, missing children and other situations requiring public attention.

title: Nobel prize in physics awarded for work unveiling the secrets of electrons
description: The 2023 Nobel prize in physics has been awarded to a trio of scientists for pioneering tools used to study the world of electrons.

title: Have some economists severely underestimated the financial hit from climate change? Recent evidence suggests yes
description: Scientists say severe climate change is now the greatest threat to humanity. Extreme weather is expected to upend lives and livelihoods, intensifying wildfires and pushing ecosystems towards collapse as ocean heat waves savage coral reefs. The threats are far-reaching and widespread.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Emotionally, he's destroyed me': Why intimate partner sexual violence needs to be taken as seriously as stranger rape
description: Last month, "That 70s Show" actor Danny Masterson was found guilty of raping two women in the early 2000s. However, the jury could not reach a verdict on a third allegation of rape involving Masterson's former girlfriend. The case, along with countless others, points to the challenges in understanding and responding to cases of intimate partner sexual violence.

title: Irrigating Australia's deserts won't increase rainfall, new modeling shows
description: ,For generations, Australians have been fascinated with the idea of turning our inland deserts green with lush vegetation.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: What is an attosecond? A physical chemist explains the tiny time scale behind Nobel Prize-winning research
description: A group of three researchers earned the 2023 Nobel Prize in physics for work that has revolutionized how scientists study the electron—by illuminating molecules with attosecond-long flashes of light. But how long is an attosecond, and what can these infinitesimally short pulses tell researchers about the nature of matter?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: From glowing cats to wombats, fluorescent mammals are much more common than you'd think
description: Recently, several mammals have been reported to "glow" under ultraviolet (UV) light, including our beloved platypus. But no one knew how common it was among mammals until now.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How insects evolved to ultrafast flight
description: Mosquitoes are some of the fastest-flying insects. Flapping their wings more than 800 times a second, they achieve their speed because the muscles in their wings can flap faster than their nervous system can tell them to beat.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New 'assembly theory' unifies physics and biology to explain evolution and complexity
description: An international team of researchers has developed a new theoretical framework that bridges physics and biology to provide a unified approach for understanding how complexity and evolution emerge in nature.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Revealing the 'secrets' of coronavirus cell entry
description: Researchers from the Utrecht University have uncovered a sophisticated mechanism by which coronavirus spike proteins can be activated for cell entry. The study, published in the journal Nature, used powerful microscopes and computer simulations to reveal how a tiny sugar molecule binds to a human coronavirus spike and triggers exposure of components that are required to invade the host cell.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change challenges marine conservation efforts in Atlantic Canada
description: Extreme ocean changes due to climate change are not an abstract or future scenario. This summer alone, 23 percent of the world's oceans experienced a heat wave, corresponding to an area roughly equivalent to the entire Atlantic Ocean.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: LGBTQ+ Americans feel they are just getting by in retirement and face greater financial risks
description: While preparing for retirement can be difficult for anyone, LGBTQ+ Americans face unique challenges that can cast a shadow over their golden years. For example, LGBTQ+ people over age 60 leave the workforce sooner, are less likely to believe that their retirement savings are on track and struggle more to pay medical bills than their straight and cisgender counterparts. They're also twice as likely to report having experienced discrimination in the past year.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: History of black corals rewritten
description: Scientists from Queensland Museum Network and the National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution have rewritten the history of black corals, revealing their origin on the continental slopes (250–3,000 meters deep) 437 million years ago.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The soil plastisphere: Effects of microplastic particles in soil
description: Plastic is everywhere in the environment, and while earlier research efforts have dealt predominantly with the ocean and aquatic systems, soil has increasingly come into focus, especially soils in agricultural ecosystems, where we grow our food.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How quantum light sees quantum sound
description: Researchers at the University of East Anglia have proposed a new way of using quantum light to "see" quantum sound.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Predictions of the effect of drugs on individual cells are now possible
description: Experts from ETH Zurich, the University of Zurich, and the University Hospital Zurich have used machine learning to jointly create an innovative method to predict how individual cells react to specific treatments, offering hope for more accurate diagnoses and therapeutics.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Growth of coral reefs likely cannot keep pace with rising sea level
description: Tropical coral reefs could end up being one of the first victims of climate change. The marine diversity hotspots are threatened and declining as a result of global warming, ocean acidification, a deterioration of water quality, as well as diseases of reef-building organisms, and their growth is unable to keep up with the projected rise in sea levels.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Lower snowfalls threatening rare High Country snowpatch ecosystem
description: A new study, "Early-melting snowpatch plant communities are transitioning into novel states," published in Scientific Reports, has found that lower snowfalls and earlier meltout has seen the ecosystem begin to transition into a new community "with an uncertain future."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Creating a 3D model of methane lake impact on local weather on Titan
description: A team of Earth and planetary scientists from the Southwest Research Institute, Yale University, Université Paris-Saclay, Universidad del País Vasco/Euskal Herriko Unibertsitatea and Sorbonne Université has created a 3D model to show the likely impact of methane lakes on local weather on Saturn's largest moon, Titan. They have published a paper on the arXiv preprint server describing the factors that went into their model and comparing it with 2D models.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Five killed by India glacial lake burst flood, 23 soldiers missing
description: At least five people have been killed and dozens including 23 soldiers are missing in India after intense rains burst a glacial lake and triggered a torrential flash flood, officials said Wednesday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Tracking the bacteria behind life-threatening sepsis in premature babies
description: Premature babies in neonatal care units are extremely vulnerable, and susceptible to life-threatening infections. To help keep these babies safe the risk of infection needs to be kept as low as possible.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Video: Why you can't recycle your pants—until now
description: Have you ever actually recycled a pair of pants or an old T-shirt?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: AI drones successfully monitor crops to report the ideal time to harvest
description: For reasons of food security and economic incentive, farmers continuously seek to maximize their marketable crop yields. As plants grow inconsistently, at the time of harvesting, there will inevitably be variations in quality and size of individual crops. Finding the optimal time to harvest is therefore a priority for farmers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Graphene oxide nanoflakes reduce the toxicity of Alzheimer's proteins, shows study
description: A probable early driver of Alzheimer's disease is the accumulation of molecules called amyloid peptides. These cause cell death and are commonly found in the brains of Alzheimer's patients. Researchers at Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden, have now shown that yeast cells that accumulate these misfolded amyloid peptides can recover after being treated with graphene oxide nanoflakes.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Same-gender sexual behavior found to be widespread across mammal species and to have multiple origins
description: A trio of ecologists from Estación Experimental de Zonas Áridas, Universidad de Granada and Centro de Investigaciones sobre Desertificación has found same-gender sexual behavior to be widespread across mammal species and report that it appears to have multiple independent origins.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: V0610 Virgo is a low-mass contact binary, observations find
description: Astronomers from the Binary Systems of South and North (BSN) project have conducted photometric observations of a distant binary star known as V0610 Virgo. Results of the observation campaign, published Sept. 23 in a research paper on the pre-print server arXiv, indicate that V0610 Virgo is a low-mass contact binary system.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study reveals novel therapeutic target to eliminate unwanted and misfolded proteins
description: Biological cells contain in-built "housekeeping" mechanisms for taking care of damaged cellular structures. This includes the ubiquitin‒proteasome system (UPS), which selectively tags unwanted proteins with the ubiquitin molecule, and then clears them. When the UPS mechanism fails, cells activate a compensatory protein clearance process called "aggrephagy," in which protein aggregates are degraded by the cell in a controlled manner. However, thus far, the mechanism behind aggrephagy has been unknown.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New sustainable way to synthesize vital fertilizer
description: QUT scientists have discovered how to produce the vital agricultural fertilizer urea at room temperature without the large energy input of the traditional production process of synthetic urea.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research quantifies how much microplastic is emitted into the atmosphere by sea spray
description: A new study quantifies the amount of microplastic exported into the atmosphere from sea spray. When bubbles burst on the surface of the sea, small particles, such as salt or bits of organic matter, can be flung into the air. This process moves significant amounts of matter, enough to affect global climate dynamics by influencing the radiative balance of the atmosphere and serving as cloud condensation nuclei. But can sea spray also toss microplastics, which are now ubiquitous in the ocean, into the atmosphere?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Socioeconomic status and power outage duration linked, finds study
description: Communities with more socioeconomic vulnerability experience longer-duration power outages than more advantaged communities, according to a study. Research has shown that environmental disasters hit economically and socially vulnerable communities hardest. The research is published in the journal PNAS Nexus.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Honeybees are more selective in their choices for nutrition than previously thought
description: Honeybees have been considered generalists when selecting flowering plants; in other words, they can use a wide range of different plants. However, recent research has shown that honeybees are quite selective.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers find barriers to driver training and licensure, especially among low-income teens
description: Researchers from the Center for Injury Research and Prevention (CIRP) at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) and the Stuart Weitzman School of Design at the University of Pennsylvania have found that teenagers living in lower-income areas of the Columbus, Ohio metro area are up to four times less likely to complete driver training and obtain their driver's license before age 18.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Living in fear on Italy's Campi Flegrei volcano
description: As a child, Alfredo Colato cooked eggs on this southern Italian volcano. Today, he is poised to flee Campi Flegrei, as experts warn earthquakes rocking his hometown could herald an eruption.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Taiwan cancels flights, shuts schools ahead of typhoon
description: Taiwan canceled flights and closed schools in parts of its southern region on Wednesday ahead of Typhoon Koinu's expected landfall, the second major storm to make a direct hit on the island in a month.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Three scientists win Nobel Prize in chemistry for their work on quantum dots
description: Three scientists won the Nobel Prize in chemistry for their work on tiny quantum dots.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A prehistoric cosmic airburst preceded the advent of agriculture in the Levant
description: Agriculture in Syria started with a bang 12,800 years ago as a fragmented comet slammed into the Earth's atmosphere. The explosion and subsequent environmental changes forced hunter-gatherers in the prehistoric settlement of Abu Hureyra to adopt agricultural practices to boost their chances for survival.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers identify underused strategy for recovering endangered species
description: During a recent review of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's recovery plans for more than 200 endangered and threatened vertebrate species in the United States, Michigan State University researchers made an interesting discovery.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Extreme fires and heavy rainfall driving platypuses from their homes
description: Australia's emerging pattern of severe mega bushfires and heavy rainfall may be driving platypuses from their homes, a new study by University of Melbourne researchers has shown.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Warming beaches threaten Yemen sea turtles' future
description: On a Yemeni beach, a sea turtle clambers ashore to lay eggs, which will likely be born female due to rising temperatures, creating a gender imbalance that brings the threat of local extinction.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Can public financing for political campaigns affect voter participation?
description: Policies that provide public financing for political campaigns have gained popularity in the United States. One example is the Democracy Vouchers program that was implemented in Seattle, Washington in 2017 to potentially reduce candidates' reliance on large donations. Research published in Contemporary Economic Policy studied the effects of this program on voter registration and turnout.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change draws great white sharks north, threatening ecosystem
description: There never used to be young great white sharks basking off the busy beaches of central California, but as climate change starts to bite, warmer waters are enticing them north—with possibly catastrophic consequences for a whole ecosystem.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Greenland's Inuit falling through thin ice of climate change
description: The thunder of icebergs crashing into the turquoise sea of eastern Greenland is the sound of one of the planet's most important ecosystems teetering on the edge of collapse.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Canada's wildfires take devastating toll on wildlife
description: No droppings, tracks, nests or other traces of wildlife—Canada's boreal forests were devastated by record wildfires this year.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Firefighters tell of hellish battle against Canada wildfires
description: Facing grueling conditions worthy of a Dantean hell, up against soaring walls of blistering flames, thousands of firefighters mobilized throughout the Canadian summer. They came out exhausted and worried for the future.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Inuit hunters blame cruise ships as narwhal disappear
description: To hunt the narwhal, whose long tusk was the unicorn horn of medieval myth, you need absolute silence.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Swedish media report that the winners of the Nobel Prize in chemistry may have been announced early
description: Swedish media say the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences may have announced the winners of this year's Nobel Prize in chemistry prematurely.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
